001package imagingbook.common.math.jama;
002
003import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.MatrixUtils;
004import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.NonSquareMatrixException;
005import org.apache.commons.math3.linear.RealMatrix;
006
007import imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic;
008import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
009
010/**
011 * Cholesky Decomposition adapted from (back-factored to) JAMA implementation 
012 * (see https://math.nist.gov/javanumerics/jama/).
013 * 
014 * This implementation is less sensitive than the Apache Commons implementation
015 * regarding rank-deficient matrices. I.e., it can also decompose matrices that
016 * are not of full rank (see the example below).
017 * <p>
018 * For a symmetric, positive definite matrix A, the Cholesky decomposition is a
019 * lower triangular matrix L so that A = L*L'.
020 * </p>
021 * <p>
022 * If the matrix is not symmetric or positive definite, the constructor returns
023 * a partial decomposition and sets an internal flag that may be queried by the
024 * {@link #isPositiveDefinite()} method.
025 * </p>
026 * 
027 * <blockquote>
028 * Original Copyright Notice: This software is a cooperative product of The MathWorks and the National Institute
029 * of Standards and Technology (NIST) which has been released to the public domain. Neither The MathWorks
030 * nor NIST assumes any responsibility whatsoever for its use by other parties, and makes no guarantees,
031 * expressed or implied, about its quality, reliability, or any other characteristic.
032 * </blockquote>
033 */
034@Deprecated 
035public class CholeskyDecomposition {
036
037    public static final double DEFAULT_RELATIVE_SYMMETRY_THRESHOLD = 1.0e-15;
038    public static final double DEFAULT_ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD = 1.0e-10;
039
040        private final double[][] L;                             // array for internal storage of decomposition
041        private final int n;                                    // row and column dimension (square matrix)
042        private final boolean isPosDefinite;    // symmetric and positive definite flag
043
044        /**
045         * 
046         * @param matrix a square, symmetric matrix to be decomposed
047         * @param relativeSymmetryThreshold 
048         *              threshold above which off-diagonal elements are considered too different and matrix not symmetric
049         * @param absolutePositivityThreshold
050         *              threshold below which diagonal elements are considered null and matrix not positive definite
051         * @throws NonSquareMatrixException if the matrix is not square
052         */
053    public CholeskyDecomposition(RealMatrix matrix, double relativeSymmetryThreshold, double absolutePositivityThreshold) {
054                if (!matrix.isSquare()) {
055                        throw new NonSquareMatrixException(matrix.getRowDimension(), matrix.getColumnDimension());
056                }
057
058                final double[][] A = matrix.getData();
059                this.n = matrix.getRowDimension();
060                this.L = new double[n][n];
061
062                boolean posDef = true;
063                for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) {
064                        final double[] Lrowj = L[j];
065                        double d = 0.0;
066                        for (int k = 0; k < j; k++) {
067                                if (Arithmetic.isZero(L[k][k])) {
068                                        throw new RuntimeException("encountered zero diagonal value at pos. " + k);
069                                }
070                                final double[] Lrowk = L[k];
071                                double s = 0.0;
072                                for (int i = 0; i < k; i++) {
073                                        s += Lrowk[i] * Lrowj[i];
074                                }
075//                              Lrowj[k] = s = (A[j][k] - s) / L[k][k];
076                                s = (A[j][k] - s) / L[k][k];
077                                Lrowj[k] = s;
078                                d = d + s * s;
079                                posDef = posDef & Arithmetic.equals(A[k][j], A[j][k], relativeSymmetryThreshold); // (A[k][j] == A[j][k]);
080                        }
081                        d = A[j][j] - d;
082                        posDef = posDef & (d > absolutePositivityThreshold);
083                        L[j][j] = Math.sqrt(Math.max(d, 0.0));
084                        for (int k = j + 1; k < n; k++) {
085                                L[j][k] = 0.0;
086                        }
087                }
088
089                this.isPosDefinite = posDef;
090    }
091    
092    
093        /**
094         * Constructor.
095         * 
096         * @param matrix a square, symmetric matrix
097         * @throws NonSquareMatrixException if the matrix is not square
098         */
099        public CholeskyDecomposition(RealMatrix matrix) {
100                this(matrix, DEFAULT_RELATIVE_SYMMETRY_THRESHOLD, DEFAULT_ABSOLUTE_POSITIVITY_THRESHOLD);
101        }
102
103
104        /**
105         * Checks if the matrix symmetric and positive definite.
106         * @return true if the decomposed matrix is symmetric and positive definite
107         */
108        public boolean isPositiveDefinite() {
109                return isPosDefinite;
110        }
111
112        /**
113         * Returns the triangular factor matrix.
114         * @return the matrix L
115         */
116        public RealMatrix getL() {
117                return MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(L);
118        }
119        
120        
121        
122

129//       * @exception RuntimeException Matrix is not symmetric positive definite.
130//       */

168        
169        
170        
171        // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
172        
173        public static void main(String[] args) {
174                        
175                /**
176                 * This symmetric 6x6 has only rank 5 and cannot be handled by Apache Common Maths's
177                 * Cholesky implementation:
178                 */
179                RealMatrix B = MatrixUtils.createRealMatrix(new double[][] {
180                        {2497883442.0, 762966565.0, 326612325.0, 15097274.0, 4845135.0, 94770.0}, 
181                        {762966565.0, 326612325.0, 188262895.0, 4845135.0, 2264945.0, 32815.0}, 
182                        {326612325.0, 188262895.0, 130208963.0, 2264945.0, 1433555.0, 17519.0}, 
183                        {15097274.0, 4845135.0, 2264945.0, 94770.0, 32815.0, 638.0}, 
184                        {4845135.0, 2264945.0, 1433555.0, 32815.0, 17519.0, 257.0}, 
185                        {94770.0, 32815.0, 17519.0, 638.0, 257.0, 5.0}});
186                
187                {
188                        System.out.println("B = \n" + Matrix.toString(B));
189                        CholeskyDecomposition cd = new CholeskyDecomposition(B);
190                        System.out.println("isPositiveDefinite = " + cd.isPositiveDefinite());
191                        RealMatrix L = cd.getL();
192                        System.out.println("L = \n" + Matrix.toString(L));
193                        System.out.println("L * LT = \n" + Matrix.toString(L.multiply(L.transpose())));
194                }
195                
196//              {
197//                      System.out.println("B = \n" + Matrix.toString(B));
198//                      org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition cd = new org.apache.commons.math3.linear.CholeskyDecomposition(B);
199//                      RealMatrix L = cd.getL();
200//                      System.out.println("L = \n" + Matrix.toString(L));
201//                      System.out.println("L * LT = \n" + Matrix.toString(L.multiply(L.transpose())));
202//              }
203                
204                
205        }
206}
